title: Derek Ogle
text:
I worked for Northland College as a fisheries and statistics professor for 26 years until 2022, when I decided to pursue my interests in a different manner. Please use the menu above to see my professional achievements and personal interests.

title: About
text:
I very much enjoy spending time with my wife Kim and our sheltie Cash (and previous shelties Jem and Jordan). In addition, I enjoy tending to our property on the Muskeg Creek; fishing, boating, and underwater photography in the summer; and cross-country skiing and snowshoeing in the winter. I also enjoy listening to music and podcasts.
Since getting an iPhone and Cash, I have also done a lot of hiking/walking followed by mapping our hikes/walks.
Not surprisingly, I also make occasional TV appearances; the most famous of these is my appearance on Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives.

title: Iron River Area Hiking/Walking
text:
For exercise and for getting to know the area in which I have lived for the last three decades, Cash and I have been walking may of the roads and back-country trails in the Iron River WI area. Below are the places we have walked thusfar. See the notes below the map for how to interact with the map. More information on specific walks can be accessed from my main hiking page.







Notes

Red is highway, Blue is paved road, Orange is gravel road, Yellow is offroad (ATV but possible 4WD vehicle), Green is trail (hiking but some ATV), and Brown is designated ATV/Snowmobile (only) trail.
Hover on track to see track abbreviation.
Click on track to get track information.
Use +/- in upper-left to zoom.
Use object in upper-right to change base map type.
Use object in lower-left to make measurements on map.

title: Music
text:
Kim and I enjoy all kinds of live music, particularly at Big Top Chautauqua, which is only an hour from home. I primarily listen to blues-rock (think SRV, KWS, etc) and outlaw country (Waylon, Willie, etc.) but we have been know to travel good distances to see Michael Franti, JJ Grey & Mofro, Ronnie Baker Brooks, and Corey Carlson.



Click the image above to see some of the musicians that we have met.

title: Our Shelties
text:
Jem
Jem was our sheltie who graced our lives from April(ish) 2009 to almost August 2018. Many people knew Jem from seeing him around the Science Center during the school year. Jem was such a special dog … very smart, incredibly loyal, and always watching over and protecting us. While he was a little snooty and often turned up his nose at “strangers”, he also melted your heart if he decided to give you the time of day. Here is a short piece that I wrote about Jem a few years ago.
Jem was taken from us way too early, though we know he is now with his “grandpa owner” taking walks, sitting on the couch together, and scheming to get those chippies. RIP “poundy”, I wish we would have had more time together, you were such a special little guy!! We will see you again (Thanks Ronnie … beautiful song).

title: Our Shelties
text:
Jordan
Jordan was the sheltie that Kim and I got soon after we were married. “Jordo” enriched our lives from April, 1991 until March 2006.
We miss the walks and boat rides. RIP “Bordo Dog”!!!

title: TV Appearances
text: Kim and I appeared, with speaking “parts”, on *Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives when Guy visited the Delta Diner, an amazing restaurant near our home.

title: TV Appearances
text:
Travel Wisconsin
I also had a cameo on a Travel Wisconsin piece about Big Top Chautauqua. Unfortunately it looks like the piece is no long available, which is OK, because for some reason they focused most clips of my wife and her family.

title: TV Appearances
text:
HS Basketball at Carver-Hawkeye
I was part of the Linn-Mar team that played the only high school basketball game at the University of Iowa’s Carver-Hawkeye Arena. If you look closely in some of these clips you can see that I had a good seat for the action!

title: About
text:
I worked for Northland College as a fisheries and statistics professor for 26 years until 2022. I believe in Northland’s mission and core values surrounding the environment, sustainability, and social justice. I very much enjoyed helping students to reach their academic and career goals.
While at Northland (and both before and since) I had opportunities to pursue my own scholarly interests. Towards that end I authored a fisheries-related book, book chapter, and several journal articles, and developed software mostly related to fisheries analyses.
My professional record is recorded on my CV and in the links above and below.

title: Publications
text:
I am sorry that I cannot provide full access to these books.




Introductory Fisheries Analyses with R
Growth Estimation: Growth Models and Statistical Inference in Age and Growth of Fishes: Principles and Techniques

title: Publications
text:
Journal Articles






Most links below are to paywalled sites. Please contact me via e-mail for a PDF of the article.




Age and Growth - Modeling

Evaluating the performance of methods used to estimate growth parameters from subsampled age data
Use and misuse of a common growth metric: guidance for appropriately calculating and reporting specific growth rate
Estimating age at a specified length from the von Bertalanffy growth function, with R Supplement
An Algorithm for the von Bertalanffy Seasonal Cessation in Growth Function of Pauly et al. (1992), with R Supplement
Clarification of Somer’s Seasonal Growth Model
Temporal Signatured Introduction
Probabilistic Age Assignments with Temporal Signatures



Age and Growth - Life History

A synthesis of the biology and ecology of sculpin species in the Great Lakes (with student)
Size and Age of Stonecats in Lake Champlain
Age, year-class strength variability, and partial age validation of Coregonus kiyi from Lake Superior Data repository (with student)
Age, Growth, and Size of Lake Superior Pygmy Whitefish (with student)
Hatchery Lake Trout Scale Characteristics



Ruffe Research

Effect of Removing Ruffe on Ruffe Populations
Ruffe Weight-Length Relationships with a Proposed Standard Weight Equation
Freezing Effect on Ruffe Length-Weight Relationships
Larval Ruffe Diet (with student)
Overview of Ruffe
Ruffe Diet and Diel Movements
Predation on Ruffe



Miscellaneous

A comparison of fish catch rates among local, non-local, and non-resident anglers of three northern Wisconsin lakes (with student)
Life history variation in Arctic charr from Cumberland Sound, Nunavut
Production dynamics reveal hidden overharvest of inland recreational fisheries
Recent Declines in Gray Jays on Christmas Bird Counts in Northern Wisconsin (with student)
Mayfly Populations in Chequamegon Bay: 2002 and 2012 (with student)
Misuse of “Gender”” in Fisheries Publications
Crayfish Trap Defense (with student)
Community and Place in Outdoor Orientation Programs - pub 1, pub 2 (with student)

title: Software
text:
FSA (Fisheries Stock Assessment): R functions to conduct typical introductory fisheries analyses. Example analyses that use FSA are in the Introductory Fisheries Analyses with R book.
FSAdata: A companion to FSA with data sets for use in common fisheries analyses.
RFishBC: Helps collect measurements from calcified structures and back-calculate estimated lengths at previous ages.







Important



These packages are now maintained by the fishR-Core-Team, of which I am a member.

title: Software
text:
Unreleased R Packages

FSAWs: For constructing and validating standard weight (Ws) equations for fish.
NCStats: Helper functions for statistics courses at Northland College.







Other packages that are less well-developed or maintained are available on my Github page

title: Software
text:
Contributions to Other R Packages

plotrix::histStack(): Construct histograms with bars stacked according to a categorical variable.
pgirmess::kruskalmc(): A generic wrapper function for performing multiple comparisons for a Kruskal-Wallis test.
car::leveneTest(): A generic wrapper function for performing Levene’s homogeneity of variances test.
plotrix::plotH(): Construct histogram-like modifications of scatterplots.
